questions.text:
Which of the following are true for a screening test?

1) Done on apparently healthy

2) Applied to individuals

3) Time-consuming

4) Relatively inaccurate results

5) Based on one criterion/ cut off
questions.solution:
Screening tests are done on apparently healthy individuals, the results of the test are relatively inaccurate, the tests are based on one criterion.

The difference between screening and diagnostic tests is given below:

Screening test Diagnostic test

Done on apparently healthy

Done on patients with signs and symptoms

Applied to groups

Applied to single patients

Based on one criterion or cut-off point

Based on evaluation of a number of symptoms, signs, and laboratory findings

Less accurate

More accurate

Less expensive

More expensive

Not a basis for treatment

Used as a basis for treatment

The initiative comes from the investigator or agency providing care

The initiative comes from a patient with a complaint

Screening tests are recommended in the following conditions:

  • Early diagnosis changes the disease course
  • In a disease with an asymptomatic stage
  • In a disease with a test for diagnosis and treatment
  • The natural history of the disease is well known

questions.text: Below is a diagram depicting the natural history of the disease. Which point marks the onset of symptoms?
questions.solution:
Point C represents a point where signs and symptoms appear.

Various points marked in the image represent the following:

Point A: Entry of infectious agent into the host.

Point B: Pathological and physiological changes occur in the stage of the subclinical phase. These changes are induced by the causative agent but are not sufficient enough to cause clinical signs and symptoms.

Point C: Marks onset of clinical signs and symptoms.

Point D: Usual time of diagnosis at which clinical signs and symptoms are well evident.

questions.text: In the following natural history of disease flowchart, point A to C is called as?
questions.solution:
Lead time is the period between the first possible time of detection (point A) and the usual time of diagnosis (point C).

Screening time is the time difference between the first point of diagnosis and the critical point of diagnosis.

Diagnosis of a disease before the critical point has a good outcome and reduces the severity by reversing the disease process. Diagnosis beyond the critical point treatment would be unsuccessful and/or permanent damage would have occurred.

Screening must be done in conditions where there is a considerable time lag between the onset of disease and the usual time of diagnosis. That is conditions with a long lead time.

Generation time is defined as the interval of time between the onset of infection by a host and the maximal infectivity of that host.

Related Pearl: Lead Time in Screening

Lead time is the period between the first possible time of detection and the usual time of diagnosis.

Lead time is the advantage gained by screening. It helps in the early diagnosis and treatment of disease. Early treatment reduces the severity by reversing the disease process.

questions.text: In which of the following diseases, screening procedure increases the overall survival to the maximum?
questions.solution:
Screening of colon cancer increases the overall survival to the maximum.

Colon cancer has a long lead time and can be detected early before pathological changes occur. It can be curable if treated early, otherwise fatal in half the cases. 

Early diagnosis and treatment before the critical point have a good outcome and reduce the severity by reversing the disease process. Diagnosis beyond the critical point treatment would be unsuccessful and/or permanent damage would have occurred.

Other diseases that can be screened are:

  • Cervical cancer
  • Breast cancer
  • Prostate cancer

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of prospective screening?

choices.text: Cervical Pap smear in a 40 year old patient
Neonatal screening of a new-born baby for hypothyroidism
Screening of immigrants to a country
Urine for sugar screening in a 40 year old man

questions.solution:
Screening of immigrants to a country is an example of prospective screening.

Screening of disease is done to detect unrecognized disease or defect, in apparently healthy individuals, by means of rapidly applied tests, examinations, or other procedures.

The difference between prospective and prescriptive screening is given below:

  Prospective screening Prescriptive screening
Definition People screened for others benefit People screened solely for their own benefit
Essential purpose Disease control Case detection
Request for screening Specific request from the authority Request from physician
Example
  • Immigrants for infectious diseases like tuberculosis syphilis, yellow fever, etc;
  • HIV screening during antenatal visits, sex workers.
  • Screening of blood donors.
  • Neonatal screening for hypothyroidism.
  • Pap smear for detection of cervical cancer.
  • Testing of urine sugar for diabetes mellitus.

Note: Most common neonatal disease to be screened for is neonatal hypothyroidism.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of multiphasic screening?

choices.text: Chest X-ray for TB in large populations
Pap smear in women above 40 years
Random blood sugar during antenatal visits

questions.solution:
Annual health checkups are an example of multiphasic screening.

Types of screening:

  1. Multiphasic screening is the application of two or more screening tests in combination with a large number of people at one time. Example- Annual health checkups.
  2. High-risk or selective screening is done on high-risk groups. Example- MRI screening of breast done annually in 25-year old women with BRCA 1, BRCA 2 mutations in a first-degree relative.
  3. Mass screening is a screening of a whole or large population like using a chest X-ray for TB screening in large populations. It is done for diseases with high prevalence.

questions.text: A large number of tests were done in series. Which of the following will be true?

choices.text: Sensitivity will decrease, specificity will increase
Sensitivity will increase, specificity will decrease

questions.solution:
When a large number of tests are done in series, net sensitivity is decreased and net specificity is increased.

Screening tests are done in series when the result of the first test determines whether to run the second test or not. e.g., HIV screening is done using consecutive ELISA.

Screening tests are done in parallel when the second test is independently performed regardless of what the first test result is. Both the tests are done at the same time. For e.g., In LFT, multiple tests are done together like SGOT, SGPT, total bilirubin, alkaline phosphatase, etc.

Following are the trends that are observed while evaluating screening tests:

  Tests in Series Tests in parallel
Combined sensitivity Decreases Increases
Combined specificity Increases Decreases
Combined PPV Increases Decreases
Combined NPV Decreases Increases

questions.text: Blood pressure is measured in an individual 5 times a day under the same conditions by a new screening test. All 5 readings obtained are the almost same. What is the attribute of a new screening test being described?
questions.solution:
The attribute of a new screening test to yield the same reading when repeated under the same conditions is called reliability.

Reliability is also called precision or reproducibility.

Related Pearl: Repeatability of a Screening Test

Repeatability is an attribute of an ideal screening test. It is also called reliability, precision, or reproducibility. It implies that the test must give consistent results when repeated on the same individual or material, under the same conditions.

It depends upon three factors:

A. Observer variation

  • All observations are subjected to variations.
  • Intra-observer variations or within-observer variations are when a single observer takes two measurements in the same subject, at the same time and obtained two different results.
  • Inter-observer variations or between-observer variations are when two different observers obtain different results on the same subject or material.
  • They are minimized by standardization of procedures, intensive training of observers, and making use of more observers.

B. Biological variation

  • It is also called subject variation.
  • They are due to changes in the parameters observed, variations in the perceptions of symptoms by patients, and regression to the mean where there is a tendency of values to be at either extreme of the distribution.

C. Errors relating to technical methods is due to the following:

  • Defective instruments
  • Erroneous calibration
  • Faulty reagents
  • Incorrect methods

questions.text:
Ten successive readings of hemoglobin level of a single sample measured by a new method are given below. The hemoglobin level measured by the previous standard test was 10.2. What is true regarding the new method?

Readings: 9.4, 10.4, 9.6, 9.1, 10.8, 12.1, 10.1, 9.8, 9.2, and 9.5.
questions.solution:
The new method for measuring hemoglobin has high validity and low reliability.

The new test doesn’t give the same values on repeat testing, thus it has low reliability. The mean value of all the readings is 10. The mean is close to the value of 10.2, which is obtained from the standard test, making the validity high.

The validity of a test implies that the test must give correct and accurate results. It represents the closeness to a true/ actual value.

The reliability of a test implies that the test must give consistent results when repeated on the same individual or material, under the same conditions.

Related Pearl: Evaluation of diagnostic tests

Different ways of asking the following parameters:

Sensitivity (True positive rate) 

  • Percentage of diseased individuals who are correctly identified (as diseased).
  • Proportion of all people with the disease who test positive.
  • Probability that when the disease is present, the test is positive.

Specificity (True negative rate) 

  • Percentage of healthy individuals who are correctly identified (as healthy).
  • Proportion of all people without the disease who test negative.
  • Probability that when the disease is absent, the test is negative.

Positive predictive value 

  • Probability that a person who has a positive test result actually has the disease.
  • If the test is positive, what is the probability that the patient has the disease?

Negative predictive value 

  • Probability that a person who has a negative test result actually does not have the disease.
  • If the test is negative, what is the probability that the patient does not have the disease?

questions.text: To calculate the positive predictive value of a new screening test for breast carcinoma, what will you use for the denominator?
questions.solution:
The denominator for the calculation of the positive predictive value of a screening test is true positives + false positives.

Positive predictive value (PPV) of a test is TP/(TP + FP) x 100.

It indicates the probability that a person with a positive test actually has the disease. It is directly proportional to the prevalence of a disease.

Predictive value is affected by sensitivity, specificity, and prevalence. However, it is affected the most by prevalence.

questions.text: Which of the following maximally affect the positive predictive value of a test?
questions.solution:
Positive predictive value (PPV) is maximally affected by the prevalence of the disease.

If the prevalence of a disease in a population is high, the high will be the positive predictive value of a screening test, and the more accurate will be the test. If the prevalence declines, the PPV will be low.

PPV is directly proportional to the prevalence of a disease. It is affected the most by prevalence. However, both sensitivity and specificity can change the predictive value.

questions.text: Screening of 100 immigrants for COVID-19 with a new test showed 48 positive and 52 people negative. Those who tested negative underwent RTPCR out of which 25 came positive. Which of the following is lowest for the new test compared to RTPCR?
questions.solution:
The sensitivity of the new screening test is low compared to RTPCR.

The new screening test showed 52 people negative, out of which 25 are detected positive by RTPCR. i.e. 25 are false negative.

The false-negative rate is the number of false-negative out of total people having the disease. 

False-negative rate = 1 - Sensitivity

The false-negative rate increases as sensitivity decreases.

In this scenario, because the new test has more false negatives, it would have low sensitivity as compared to RTPCR.

questions.text: While screening a disease with a new screening test, the test is positive in many patients who actually don't have the disease. Which of the following is true?
questions.solution:
The given new screening test has low specificity.

The test is positive in many patients who actually don't have the disease, i.e. high false positives.

The false-positive rate is the number of false positives out of total non-diseased.

False-positive rate = 1-Specificity

The false-positive rate is inversely proportional to specificity. Hence, the given test with high false positives will have low specificity.

Positive predictive value (PPV)= TP/TP+FP. It shows the positive predictive value(PPV) of the test decreases with an increase in false positives. 

An increase in the false-positive does not affect the prevalence of the disease. The prevalence of a disease depends on the incidence(I) and duration(D) of the disease.

Prevalance= I x D

questions.text: Due to an effective prevention program, the prevalence of a disease in a community has been reduced by 90%. However, the physicians continue to use the same screening test for that disease. Which of the following changes is expected to be seen?
questions.solution:
If the prevalence of the disease falls, the negative predictive value(NPV) increases.

The NPV of the test is inversely proportional to the prevalence of a disease.

The PPV of the test is directly proportional to the prevalence of a disease.

Sensitivity and specificity are independent of the prevalence of the disease in the area. They do not change with the change in prevalence.

questions.text: In a population of 10000, the prevalence of a disease is 20%. The sensitivity of a screening test is 95% and specificity is 80%. What is the positive predictive value of the test?
questions.solution:
The positive predictive value (PPV) of the test is 54.3%.

The prevalence of the disease is 20% in 10000, i.e., 2000 people have the disease(TP + FN) and 8000 are disease-free (FP + TN).

The sensitivity of the test is 95%, i.e. TP/(TP + FN) = 95%.

Thus, the true positives (TP)= 95/100 x (TP + FN) = 95/100 x 2000 = 1900.

The specificity of the test is 80%, i.e. TN/(FP + TN) = 80%.

Thus, the true negatives (TN)= 80/100 x (FP + TN) = 80/100 x 8000 = 6400.

questions.text: The prevalence of the disease 'X' in a population is 30%. The diagnostic test for this disease has a specificity of 0.80 and a sensitivity of 0.90. What is the negative predictive value of the test?
questions.solution:
The negative predictive value of the above test is 95%.

For convenience, let us assume that the total population in this scenario is 100.

The prevalence of the disease is 30%. So the total number of people with the disease is 30(TP+FN) and disease-free(FP+TN) is 70.

Since sensitivity is 0.90, i.e. TP/(TP + FN) = 90%.

The total true positives (TP) = 90/100 x (TP+FN) = 90/100 x 30 = 27

False-negative(FN) = 30-27 = 3

Since specificity is 0.80, i.e. TN/(FP+TN) = 80%.

Total true negatives (TN) =(FP+TN) x 80/100 = 70 x 80/100 = 56

False-positive(FP) = 70-56 = 14

questions.text: Which of the following is best for determining the threshold for diagnosis of a positive test?
questions.solution:
The receiver operator characteristic curve is the best for determining the threshold for the diagnosis of a positive test. It is also used for the comparison of two or more screening/ diagnostic tests of disease with each other.

The following is an example of a ROC curve for a screening test.

questions.text: Which curve from the given image reflects a better test?
questions.solution:
Test A is the best test among the four given, as it has the highest sensitivity and the lowest false positive rate (100-specificity).

A receiver operating characteristic curve(ROC) is obtained by plotting a test's true positive rate (sensitivity) against its false-positive rate ( 100- specificity) for different diagnostic cut-off points. 

The shape of the curve reflects the quality of the test. The better the test, the more it moves to the upper left (more the area under the curve). For a good test, sensitivity comes close to 100% on the y-axis, and the false positive rate comes close to 0% on the x-axis.

questions.text: Observe the following curves, which of the following is a true statement about sensitivity and specificity when the curve changes from green to pink?
questions.solution:
Both sensitivity and specificity are higher in the test represented in pink (Test B) compared to the test represented in green (Test A).

Sensitivity is the proportion of all people with the disease who test positive. It is the probability of the test being positive when the disease is present.

Sensitivity = TP / (TP + FN) or Sensitivity = 1 – false-negative rate.

Specificity is the proportion of all people without the disease who test negative. It is the probability of the test being negative when the disease is absent.

Specificity= TN / (TN + FP) or specificity= 1 – false-positive rate.

Test B has an increased number of true positives and true negatives and decreased number of false positives and negatives, compared to Test A. 

Hence leading to increased sensitivity and specificity.
